summary: This is a legal opinion from French attorney William Julie, submitted as an exhibit in opposition to the U.S. government's memorandum regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's potential extradition. The document analyzes French extradition law, critiques the government's reliance on a 2007 case (Peterson), and argues that France has discretion to extradite its citizens to the U.S. under existing treaties.

persons.name: William Julie
persons.context: Author of the legal opinion analyzing French extradition law and arguing against the U.S. government's position that France would not extradite Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the extradition discussion; the document argues that France would likely extradite her to the United States if requested.

persons.name: Hans Peterson
persons.context: Subject of a 2007 extradition case where France denied his extradition to the U.S.; cited by the U.S. government as precedent.

persons.name: Richard J. Durbin
persons.context: Co-authored a 2007 letter to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs regarding the Peterson extradition case, cited in the document.

persons.name: Barack Obama
persons.context: Co-authored a 2007 letter to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs regarding the Peterson extradition case, cited in the document.

connections.description: William Julie provides legal analysis regarding Maxwell's potential extradition from France to the United States.
Co-authored a 2007 letter to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs regarding the Peterson extradition case.
Subject of a 2007 extradition request from the U.S. that was denied by French authorities.

events.title: France denies Peterson extradition
events.description: French Minister of Justice communicated decision refusing extradition of dual citizen Hans Peterson to the United States.

events.title: Durbin-Obama letter to France
events.description: U.S. Senators Richard Durbin and Barack Obama wrote to French Minister of Foreign Affairs urging discretion to be exercised in favor of extradition in the Peterson case.

events.title: EU-U.S. Extradition Agreement生效
events.description: Agreement on extradition between the European Union and the United States of America came into force, enhancing cooperation.

events.title: French Minister of Justice letter
events.description: French Minister of Justice wrote a letter (Exhibit B) regarding extradition of French citizens, cited by U.S. government in opposition to Maxwell's release.

locations: 51, Rue Ampere - 75017 Paris (William Julie's law office address)
keyFacts: French attorney William Julie argues that France has discretion to extradite its citizens to the U.S. under the U.S.-France Extradition Treaty and EU-U.S. Agreement.
The document critiques the U.S. government's reliance on the 2007 Peterson case, noting it was a discretionary ministerial decision, not a binding judicial precedent.
Julie contends that Article 3 of the U.S.-France Extradition Treaty does not preclude extradition of French nationals; it merely states there is no obligation to do so.
The analysis emphasizes that under Article 55 of the French Constitution, international treaties prevail over national legislation on extradition matters.
The opinion concludes it is 'highly unlikely' France would refuse to extradite Ghislaine Maxwell, especially if she signed an irrevocable waiver in the U.S.
